bestBHT.bht: Though Joseph of Arimathea was a member of the council that condemned Jesus, he did not agree with their decision or give his consent. Unlike the others, he had not participated in their determination against Jesus. He had not approved of their counsel and deed. In fact, it is quite clear that Joseph and Nicodemus were suspected of sympathy with Jesus and were not even invited to his trial. It is evident that Joseph's allegiance was to God's kingdom rather than the schemes of men.

Henry Alford: The meaning is, he had absented himself, and taken no part in their (the council’s) determination against Jesus.
There is no reference to the lighting of candles in the evening or on the sabbath.
Lightfoot has shewn that such use of the word wa s common among the Jews, who called the evening (the beginning) of a day, ‘light.’
Marvin Vincent: Consented [συγκατατεθειμενος] . Only here in New Testament.
The verb means to put [τιθημι] , down [κατα] , along with [συν] .
Hence to put down the same vote or opinion with another : to agree with or assent to.
Archibald T. Robertson: He had not consented to their counsel and deed.
This parenthesis is given by Luke alone and explains that, though a councillor, he had not agreed to the vote of the Sanhedrin.
It is fairly certain that both Joseph and Nicodemus were suspected of sympathy with Jesus and so were not invited to the trial of Jesus.
John Gill: Though he was with the Jews, the chief priests, Scribes, and elders, in the high priest's palace, being one of that great council; yet he did not agree with them; nor was it his advice and counsel, that they should put Christ to death; he was against it, at least did not consent to it."
He was of Arimathea, a city of the Jews.
Who also himself waited for the kingdom of God.

bhtAttempts.bht: Though Joseph of Arimathea was a member of the council that condemned Jesus, he did not agree with their decision or give his consent. Unlike the others, he had not participated in their determination against Jesus. He had not approved of their counsel and deed. In fact, it is quite clear that Joseph and Nicodemus were suspected of sympathy with Jesus and were not even invited to his trial. It is evident that Joseph's allegiance was to God's kingdom rather than the schemes of men.

Though Joseph of Arimathea, a member of the council, was present during the trial of Jesus, he did not consent to their decision. He had not agreed with their counsel and deed, as he was suspected of sympathy towards Jesus and was not invited to the trial. Joseph's allegiance was to God's kingdom, and he awaited its coming. He distinguished himself from the rest of the council, who had determined against Jesus, by showing his dissent and refusal to participate in their actions.

Though a member of the council, Joseph of Arimathea did not consent to their decision or agree with their counsel and deed. He had distanced himself from their determination against Jesus. Joseph's allegiance was to God's kingdom, as he awaited its arrival. He differed from the rest of the council, who had determined against Jesus, by showing his dissent and refusal to participate in their actions.

Though Joseph of Arimathea was a member of the council, he had not consented to their counsel and deed. He distinguished himself from the others by dissociating himself from their determination against Jesus. Joseph's allegiance was towards the coming of God's kingdom, which he eagerly anticipated. It is worth noting that he and Nicodemus were suspected of sympathizing with Jesus, resulting in their exclusion from his trial. Joseph's non-participation in their actions reveals his dissent and refusal to align with their decisions.

Joseph of Arimathea, though a member of the council, did not consent to their counsel and deed against Jesus. This distinguished him from his peers who had determined against Jesus. It is believed that Joseph and Nicodemus, due to their suspected sympathy for Jesus, were not invited to his trial. Joseph's allegiance was to the kingdom of God, eagerly awaited its arrival. His dissent and refusal to participate in their actions highlight his opposition to their decisions.
